properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme cold wind chills tonight into Thursday morning. Extreme cold wind chill values near or below minus 45 are forecast to develop tonight and then continue into Thursday morning. After moderating Thursday afternoon, the extreme cold wind chill values are expected to redevelop Thursday night into Friday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-06T08:22:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-05T16:23:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1351618947.2020
Area: Fort Severn, Sachigo Lake - Bearskin Lake, Big Trout Lake - Kasabonika
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An Arctic ridge of high pressure has brought morning temperatures in the mid minus thirties. These bitterly cold temperatures combined with 10 km/h winds to produce extremely cold wind chills of minus 45 or colder this morning. These wind chills will ease somewhat through the day but extreme wind chills are expected to return on Wednesday night into Thursday morning. Milder temperatures are expected by late week as the ridge of high pressure moves off to the east and cloud cover increases. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-06T02:18:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-05T10:19:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2362527899.2020
Area: Brochet, Tadoule Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 5 to 20 cm ending this morning. A favourable set up for low elevation snow over the south coast will continue this morning. A front has tracked down the BC coast and combined with a cool airmass to produce snow across the lowlands. Snowfall amounts have varied significantly across the region and up to 15 cm of heavy, wet snow has fallen overnight. An additional 5 cm is expected this morning for the central and eastern Fraser Valley. Over the western Fraser Valley including Abbotsford snow has become mixed with rain overnight. Significant widespread snow accumulation is no longer expected, but local amounts of 2 to 4 cm of heavy wet snow is still possible early this morning. Precipitation will change to rain later this morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-06T01:49:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-05T12:49:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3130749363.2020
Area: Fraser Valley - central including Chilliwack, Fraser Valley - east including Hope

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow expected Thursday night to Saturday morning.. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 80 km/h. Locations: Western, central and northeastern Newfoundland. Time span: Thursday night through Saturday afternoon. Remarks: Precipitation will begin as snow in the south Thursday night and spread to the remainder of the Island throughout the day on Friday. Snow will likely mix at times with ice pellets and freezing rain on Friday night, with a slight chance of a few hours of rain or drizzle. Snow will taper off on Saturday morning in the west, and by Saturday afternoon in the northeast. On Saturday, increasing winds and falling temperatures will accompany the snow and generate blowing snow giving reduced visibilities, especially over exposed areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-06T11:18:09-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts near 30 cm is expected A Pacific warm front will move into the BC interior today leading to a prolonged period of snow for Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass. Periods of snow today will intensify this evening. Snow at times heavy will continue Thursday. Total snowfall amounts greater than 30 cm are expected by Thursday afternoon. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and ice pellets possible tonight into Thursday. A low from Texas is expected to move towards the lower Great Lakes on Thursday. Snow associated with the low will arrive tonight, and may turn to ice pellets across the region before coming to an end later Thursday. There is also a risk of freezing rain. Total snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are possible. There is still some uncertainty as to the exact track of the low, which will affect how far north into the region the ice pellets or freezing rain will occur. The Thursday morning commute to work will be impacted. Environment Canada is closely monitoring this situation. Appropriate weather warnings may be issued as this event draws closer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-06T08:45:59-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A mix of significant winter weather expected Thursday night to Saturday afternoon. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Total Freezing rain (duration): 15 to 30 mm (4 to 8 hours). Total rainfall: 25 to 50 mm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 to 100 km/h from the southwest. Locations: southern and eastern Newfoundland. Time span: Thursday night through Saturday afternoon. Remarks: Precipitation will begin as snow in the south Thursday night and spread to the remainder of the Island throughout the day on Friday. The snow is expected to transition through ice pellets and freezing rain and eventually over to rain over southeastern Newfoundland Friday and Friday night as temperatures gradually rise above zero. An extended period of freezing precipitation is likely during this time. Rainfall will be most significant over the Burin and southern Avalon peninsulas. The system is also expected to bring a combination of storm surge and large waves and pounding surf to Newfoundland's south coast. Higher than normal water levels and a risk of coastal flooding will be possible on Saturday morning, especially near high tide for communities exposed to the southwest. Conditions are expected to improve throughout the day on Saturday as the system moves out to sea. Precipitation will likely taper off to showers and flurries on Saturday morning, while strong southwesterly winds continue into the afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-06T11:19:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-05T19:20:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3080529173.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, freezing rain and rain expected late week. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Total rainfall: 15 to 25 mm. Freezing rain duration: 4 to 8 hours. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h or higher. Locations: most of Newfoundland. Time span: Thursday night through Saturday morning. Remarks: Precipitation will begin as snow in the south Thursday night and spread to the remainder of the Island throughout the day on Friday. The snow is expected to transition through ice pellets and freezing rain and eventually over to rain over southeastern Newfoundland Friday and Friday night as temperatures gradually rise above zero. An extended period of freezing precipitation is likely during this time. Snowfall will be highest over western, central and northeastern regions with significant accumulations possible. On Friday night, increasing winds and falling temperatures will accompany the snow and generate blowing snow giving reduced visibilities, especially over exposed areas. The system is also expected to bring large waves, pounding surf, higher than normal water levels and a risk of coastal flooding to southern parts of the Island Saturday morning, especially near high tide. Conditions are expected to improve throughout the day on Saturday as the system moves out to sea, though gusty northerly winds behind the system will continue throughout the day giving flurries and blowing snow in the onshore flow and as temperatures drop. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-06T06:28:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-05T14:29:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0960252852.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, ice pellets and freezing rain expected for the end of the week. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm, possibly more over Prince County. Locations: Prince Edward Island. Time span: Thursday afternoon to Saturday morning. Remarks: Periods of snow will begin Thursday afternoon and persist Thursday night. A changeover to ice pellets and/or freezing rain is likely on Friday before changing back to snow Friday night. Strong easterly winds Friday night into Saturday morning may also cause reduced visibility in snow and blowing snow. Snow is expected to taper off Saturday morning. There remains some uncertainty in where the changeover to mixed precipitation will occur, which will affect the amount and location of the heaviest snowfall and the areas most likely to be threatened by freezing rain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, ice pellets and freezing rain expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 30+ cm for parts of south, central and northern New Brunswick. 5 to 10 cm along the Fundy coast. Locations: New Brunswick. Time span: Thursday morning to Saturday morning. Remarks: Periods of snow will begin in the southwest Thursday morning and spread north across the rest of the province throughout the day. Parts of southern New Brunswick will likely see a changeover to ice pellets and freezing rain Thursday night then change back over to snow Friday night. A significant period of freezing rain is possible over southern New Brunswick. Strong easterly winds Friday night into Saturday morning may also cause reduced visibility in snow and blowing snow. Snow is expected to taper off Saturday morning. There remains uncertainty in how far north the changeover to mixed precipitation will occur which will affect the amount and location of the heaviest snowfall expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills continues. The coldest wind chill values will be near minus 55. Extreme cold conditions will end later this morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, and possible ice pellets and freezing rain for the end of the week. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm, possibly more. Locations: Iles-de-la-Madeleine. Time span: Thursday evening to Saturday morning. Remarks: Periods of snow will begin Thursday evening and persist overnight. There is potential for a changeover to ice pellets and/or freezing rain during the day Friday before changing back to snow Friday night. Strong easterly winds Friday night into Saturday morning may also cause reduced visibility in snow and blowing snow. Snow is expected to taper off Saturday morning. There remains some uncertainty in where the changeover to mixed precipitation will occur, which will affect the amount and location of the heaviest snowfall expected and the areas most likely to be threatened by freezing rain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-06T11:32:10-00:00

Area: Îles-de-la-Madeleine
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and ice pellets possible tonight into Thursday. A low from Texas is expected to move towards the lower Great Lakes on Thursday. Snow associated with the low will arrive tonight, and may turn to ice pellets across the region before coming to an end later Thursday. There is also a risk of freezing rain. Total snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are possible. There is still some uncertainty as to the exact track of the low, which will affect how far north into the region the ice pellets or freezing rain will occur. The Thursday morning commute to work will be impacted. Environment Canada is closely monitoring this situation. Appropriate weather warnings may be issued as this event draws closer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-06T07:58:37-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Strong westerlies will whip up the snow and reduce visibilities in the blizzard. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: MIxed precipitation expected for the end of the week. Location: Nova Scotia. Time span: Thursday morning to Saturday morning. Remarks: Snow will begin in the southwest Thursday morning and spread north across the rest of the province throughout the day. The snow is expected to change over to ice pellets and freezing rain over most of Nova Scotia Thursday night, and an extended period of freezing rain is possible Thursday night and Friday as temperatures hover near zero. In the southwest, however, a changeover to rain is expected on Thursday. There remains uncertainty in how far north the changeover to mixed precipitation will occur which will affect the amount and location of the most intense freezing rain and rain. Warnings may be issued with future forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
